newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent firmer on Iraq concern before OPEC talks.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent firmer on Iraq concern before OPEC talks.

text.p: IPE Brent floated gently higher on Monday morning following a firm opening amid continued concern over tension between the United Nations and Iraq, traders and brokers said.
August Brent was trading at $17.95 a barrel at 1210 GMT, a gain of 28 cents from Friday's close, while July gas oil was $2.00 a tonne up at $160.50.
"There is nothing too new recently but the problems between Iraq and the U.N. has caused a bit of concern," one broker said.
The U.N. Security Council adopted a resolution over the weekend threatening Iraq with further sanctions if it does not allow U.N. arms inspectors to search sensitive sites.
It also suspended until the end of October regular 60 day reviews of current sanctions.
"The market on Friday did not expect to see such a negative U.N. stand on the Iraqi situation and I think the market is reacting to that today," one dealer said.
Ministers were starting to arrive in Vienna for this week's OPEC conference but brokers said this was not having an immediate impact.
"Things are always quiet pre-OPEC," one said. "There is a general consensus that there will be a roll over of their quotas but you never know what surprises they are going to come up with."
Technical traders were eyeing the key chart gap between $17.98 and $18.00 a barrel as the focus for resistance.
